Article Title: Why Kevin Durant Said NO: The Real Reason He Killed Potential Golden State Warriors Trade

Kevin Durant on Warriors-Suns trade veto, Steph Curry & BEST NBA era | Draymond Green & Baron Davis

Kevin Durant , the NBA's resident enigma wrapped in a 7-foot frame, recently dropped a truth bomb that sent ripples through the basketball universe. Forget cryptic tweets and vague Instagram stories; he went straight to the source, The Draymond Green Show , to explain why a potential Golden State Warriors reunion was a hard "no." It wasn't about burning bridges or holding grudges, it was about something far more relatable: the sheer, soul-crushing exhaustion of mid-season upheaval.Durant's dedication to the Phoenix Suns was indeed a factor, but the core of his decision was rooted in the simple, human desire for stability. "I didn't want to move," he declared, echoing the sentiments of anyone who's ever dreaded packing boxes. He'd been through the whirlwind of team changes before, and the prospect of another mid-season shakeup, especially with the trade deadline looming, was simply too much. "It’s just such a big change, and I’ve been through it before," he explained, painting a picture of a player weary of constant transitions.Think of it like this: imagine moving apartments, not just once, but multiple times, always in the middle of a work project. The stress of packing, unpacking, and adjusting to a new environment while trying to perform at peak levels is immense. Durant, a player who costs "a lot," recognized the disruptive impact a mid-season trade would have on any team. "Me just getting up and moving in the middle of the season, it’s going to be a big blow to any team I’m going to," he stated, highlighting the logistical and emotional toll of such a move.Beyond the personal disruption, Durant also expressed a commitment to the Suns' journey. He wanted to see what the team could achieve, especially after the departure of key players like Cam Johnson and Mikal Bridges . "I’m trying to see this through to the end and see what we can really do with it," he emphasized, underscoring his loyalty to his coaches and teammates. He wanted to give the Phoenix experiment a fair shot, to see if they could forge something special together.ALSO READ: Why Did Los Angeles Lakers Tribute Video Hit Anthony Davis So Hard? His Reaction Says It All Adding a touch of nostalgia, Durant reflected on his time playing with NBA legends LeBron James and Stephen Curry . He spoke of a unique connection with Curry, a silent understanding honed through years of shared experience. "I felt like I was the only one on the court who knew what he was thinking," he recalled, referencing their time together during the 2024 Summer Olympics. This glimpse into their unspoken chemistry highlighted the deep bonds formed in the crucible of elite competition, reminding us that even in the high-stakes world of professional sports, human connections remain paramount.

Article Title: Boris Spassky Soviet chess grandmaster dies at 88
Article Text:
File Pic: Boris Spassky, left and Bobby Fischer analyse their match in Sveti Stefan, Yugoslavia in 1992. (AP Photo)

Go Beyond The Boundary with our YouTube channel.

The Russian Chess Federation announced on Thursday that Boris Spassky , the Soviet chess grandmaster, has passed away at 88 years old. He gained global recognition for his historic 1972 match against American Bobby Fischer during the Cold War."The tenth world champion Boris Spassky has died at 88," stated the federation, describing it as a "great loss for the country."Spassky's legacy centres on the 1972 World Chess Championship against Fischer, a contest that reflected the political tensions between the United States and Soviet Union.After becoming world champion in 1969, Spassky faced significant pressure to uphold Soviet chess supremacy, which had persisted since 1948. Although he initially led the match, Fischer staged a remarkable recovery, defeating him and ending Soviet control of the world title.Following the match, Spassky revealed that losing brought unexpected relief, as it released him from what he termed a "colossal responsibility."Born in Leningrad (present-day Saint Petersburg) in 1937, Spassky displayed exceptional chess talent early, claiming the World Junior Championship and becoming the youngest grandmaster at age 18.His famous contest with Fischer has inspired numerous creative works, including books, documentaries and films. The match also influenced Walter Tevis's novel The Queen's Gambit , later adapted into a successful Netflix series in 2020.
Article Summary: Boris Spassky, the Soviet chess grandmaster, has passed away at 88 years old. He gained global recognition for his historic 1972 match against American Bobby Fischer during the Cold War. His famous contest with Fischer has inspired numerous creative works, including books, documentaries and films.

Gracie Hunt , daughter of Kansas City Chiefs ' owner and CEO Clark Hunt , recently took a moment to reflect on a whirlwind month that was filled with anticipation, excitement, and ultimately, heartbreak. Sharing her journey on Instagram on February 27, Hunt posted a heartfelt recap titled "The February Files," capturing moments from her eventful month leading up to the highly anticipated 2025 Super Bowl. Despite the Kansas City Chiefs' dreams of a historic "three-peat" being shattered by a decisive 40-22 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles , Hunt's gratitude and resilience shone through her emotional reflections.The Kansas City Chiefs entered the 2025 Super Bowl with sky-high hopes, aiming for a historic third consecutive championship. Finishing the regular season with an impressive 15-2 record, the Chiefs were poised to etch their names in NFL history. However, the Super Bowl did not unfold as planned. The Philadelphia Eagles delivered a crushing blow, leaving the Chiefs scoreless in the first half while quarterback Patrick Mahomes struggled, throwing two critical interceptions. Although the Chiefs made a valiant effort in the second half, the deficit proved insurmountable, and the Eagles secured a dominant 40-22 victory.Reflecting on all thos that happened, Hunt wrote,"feeling thankful for every moment that shapes life’s beautiful mosaic," including "the tough, the painful, the joyful, and everything in between.""Most of all, I’m grateful for the incredible people who make it all worthwhile,” she added in the caption.In the wake of this heartbreaking loss, Gracie Hunt showed remarkable grace and perspective. Reflecting on the defeat, she shared, “Praise Him when you win. Praise Him when you lose. It wasn’t the result we were hoping for, but so proud of this team’s heart and the incredible season we had.” Despite the disappointment, Hunt's words revealed her unwavering faith and gratitude for the journey. She expressed her appreciation for "every moment that shapes life’s beautiful mosaic," embracing both the highs and lows that come with the sport. Her post also conveyed her deep admiration for the Chiefs’ loyal fanbase, calling them the “best fans in the NFL” and promising that the reigning AFC champions will “be back.”Beyond the field, Gracie Hunt’s influence extends into the Kansas City Chiefs community. In an exclusive interview with PEOPLE on January 16, Hunt spoke about her passion for the team and her commitment to making a positive impact. Describing herself as the Chiefs’ “No. 1 fan,” she emphasized the importance of faith, family, football, and philanthropy in her life. Reflecting on her upbringing, she shared, "I've always been raised with the mantra that, 'To whom much is given, much is expected'."Also Read: “I owe it to my teammates”: Travis Kelce announces he’s not retiring yet, ensuring more game-day support from Taylor Swift Hunt’s involvement in the Chiefs’ organization goes beyond mere fandom. I'd say the beauty about our family organization is that there's a place for everyone.”

Article Title: How Virat Kohli tweaked technique after Australia tour
Article Text:
BACK TO BANGAR

INCREASED BACK FOOT PLAY

He (Kohli) waited for the ball to come to him. He really wasn't on the front foot all the time. He was willing to cover the infield as well. Against spin, what was good to see in the first half of his innings was that he was playing a lot off the back foot. Then once he got that confidence, he started coming forward. So, starting off the back foot and then gradually going on to the front foot was the plan. Sanjay Bangar

ALTERED BAT POSITIONING

When Kohli was in form, his bat used to come from the second or third slip area, allowing him to play more controlled shots. He is a guy who leaves no stone unturned as far as preparation is concerned. He knew that he had to step up (after the Australia tour). He brought that intensity to his game, and one could see it in his body language. Sanjay Bangar

ADJUSTMENT IN STANCE

One of the fittest cricketers around, the former India captain last missed a match — before the Nagpur ODI — more than three years ago, the Johannesburg Test against South Africa in Jan 2022. Fit and raring to go, the star batter was the first to hit the nets and batted for nearly an hour before leaving the ground first, shouldering his cricket coffin.While England completely skipped Saturday's practice, many India players also skipped the optional session, including last-match hero Shreyas Iyer , vice-captain Shubman Gill , debutant Harshit Rana, comeback man Mohammed Shami, Hardik Pandya and Axar Patel."Virat Kohli is fit to play. He has come for practice and is good to go," batting coach Sitanshu Kotak said during the prematch media interaction.With a fit-again Kohli back in the playing XI, India will face a selection dilemma as they prepare to tick all the boxes ahead of the Champions Trophy and seal the series before going to Ahmedabad.Will Iyer lose his place to Kohli if the team management decides to continue with Yashasvi Jaiswal to keep the left-right opening combination going with captain Rohit Sharma ? Kotak, however, bypassed any queries on who should make way for Kohli on Sunday."I think that's what the head coach and captain can talk about. Article Title: Former UK PM Rishi Sunak plays cricket in Mumbai, 'Managed not to get out too many times'
Article Text:
Former British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak on Sunday visited the Parsee Gymkhana in south Mumbai and enjoyed a game of cricket, asserting he was happy that he did not get out too many times.

Former British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak swapped politics for cricket on Sunday, picking up a bat at the iconic Parsee Gymkhana in south Mumbai. Participating in the club’s anniversary celebrations, Sunak showcased his cricketing skills in a game of tennis ball cricket , later joking that he was relieved to have stayed at the crease longer than expected.“No trip to Mumbai is complete without a game of tennis ball cricket,” Sunak wrote on X, sharing glimpses of the match. Speaking to reporters, he added, “Great to be with all of you at the Parsee Gymkhana Club at its anniversary celebrations. What an extraordinary achievement. So much history and so much exciting stuff to come. I managed not to get out too many times this morning.”The Parsee Gymkhana, founded in 1885 by Sir Jamsetjee Jejeebhoy and Jamsetjee Tata, has played a key role in shaping Indian cricket history. It moved to its current location along Marine Drive in 1887 and remains a symbol of Mumbai’s deep-rooted cricketing culture.Sunak, who has often spoken about his love for cricket, seemed to enjoy the nostalgic moment. He hinted at more such visits in the future, saying he looked forward to coming back.

According to the, some also sang "Lizzie’s in a box," referring to the late Queen Elizabeth II . There were also clashes between fans in the stands.Prince William, an Aston Villa supporter, attended the match as his team won 4-2 and secured a place in the last 16 of the Champions League. He was seen celebrating Villa’s goals.Earlier this month, he also traveled to Monaco to watch Aston Villa play in the Champions League.
